channel.title: Writing Configuration Files
channel.description:
So, it's been part of my Downloader project for quite some times, but never quite grasped the concept.
So, this is what I think I'm supposed to do: Name a FileOutputStream.. Use the path to config: "Config/config.ini"... And use setProperties(String, String).
Now, my problem is it hasn't been working :P It finds the file, only because I don't get any exceptions, but the properties aren't changing.
Can anyone give me an example?

item.title: Writing Configuration Files
item.dc:creator: @Pwnd Pwnd
item.description:
@Pwnd wrote:

Actually, Bob, I hadn’t used anything

Read full topic

item.description:
@White_Castle wrote:

Hah. Thanks Bob, this helped me too. I needed teh XML for my RuneScape server.

item.title: Writing Configuration Files
item.dc:creator: @BobDole81 BobDole81
item.description:
@BobDole81 wrote:

Yes, It’s missing a ) for the FileOutputStream object…I’ll fix that

What did you use instead of store()? save() is basically the same thing, but apparantly doesn’t throw an IOException and therefore is depreciated (or something like that). You can also store it as XML, which is a useful option.

Anyway, glad you got it to work

Read full topic

item.title: Writing Configuration Files
item.dc:creator: @Pwnd Pwnd
item.description:
@Pwnd wrote:

Well, I almost did it exactly how you just presented, except my I didn’t use the store() method ;D. I’m going to assume that’s my problem.

Let me get this completely straight. The last line looks fishy ;D Or, it’s just your missing a ‘)’ at the end

By the way, I’m recoding the entire downloader, so this’ll definately bring a working change xD

Thanks again, Bob

Read full topic

item.title: Writing Configuration Files
item.dc:creator: @BobDole81 BobDole81
item.description:
@BobDole81 wrote:

Try something like this:

java.util.Properties configProperties = new java.util.Properties();
configProperties.setProperty("someKey", "someValue");
configProperties.setProperty("someKey1", "someValue2");
configProperties.store(new java.io.FileOutputStream("./Config/config.ini", "Some Comments");

Mind showing how you did it as well, though, so you know what you did wrong?

Read full topic
